title: Learn How to Not Fall
published_date: studies show that a large number of individuals with MS

content: According to the Cleveland Clinic, “Published studies show that a large number of individuals with MS (50% to 70%) experience at least one fall over a 6-month period, and 30% to 50% of those who fall experience recurrent falls.”

Doctors define falling as any unintentional change in position that leaves a person on the ground. Falls can be gentle, like sliding off a low chair onto a carpeted floor, or more traumatic, like tripping over a curb and banging your head on the pavement. They are a major cause of hospitalization in people with MS.

The MS Society says falls damage lives in two ways. We can be physically injured, from bumps and bruises up to broken bones. Fear of falling also cripples people. It can lead to restricting our activities, which can lead to social isolation. Being afraid to stand may cut into our exercise, making us weaker in a vicious cycle.

I fell about five years ago and chipped my pelvis. It really hurt, and I was stuck in bed for almost a week. Studies show that 40% to 50% of people with MS are injured in falls at some point in their lives. The risk of fracture from falls increases as bones get weaker (called osteoporosis). Weak bones commonly happen to people with decreased mobility.

sections.heading: Why People With MS Fall So Often
content: MS puts people at risk of falls in several ways. We may not have a good sense of balance. We may be slow to realize we’re tipping over. We may not think clearly (as in, “Can I make it down those stairs or not?”). General muscle weakness might make it easy for legs to give out and hard for arms to hold us up.
Foot drop is a common reason for falls. That’s when we try to pick our foot up, like onto a thick carpet, but the front of the foot stays down and trips us. I’ve had that happen.
Medication effects can make muscles weaker. This especially happens with drugs for muscle spasms and tremors.

content: Another problem is not using a needed mobility device or using the wrong one, like a cane when a walker is needed. I wrote about this last month; some people are too proud for their own good. Rather than use assistance, they’ll risk a fall, or they’ll stay home or stay in bed, which puts them at greater risk when they do get out.

content: I find warm environments to be the biggest risk factor for me. Other environmental dangers are throw rugs and cracked sidewalks. Stairs and bathrooms pose the most risk for many of us. Really bad falls happen in bathrooms because of all the hard surfaces we can collide with.
Preventing Falls
People from our WebMD Facebook community posted several ways they avoid falls.
Rene says, “I walk with a wider stance and try to lift my feet higher, and I take my time.”
Diane steadies herself by keeping her hands on walls or furniture.

Several people said they walk slower and try to stay mindful of their steps and of things that might be in their way. Others use mobility aids such as rollators. Maya has a lovely aid, her husband’s hand, which she holds when they walk.
Like people with MS, all older people have an increased risk of falls, and my local public health department gives lots of relevant advice. I’ll add some of my own here:
bullets: Remove throw rugs and thick carpets.
Remove clutter – no toys or pet stuff in walkways.
Nothing should be out on your stairs.
Do regular strength and balance exercises.
Homes should be well lit, especially stairways.
Put nonskid mats on bathroom and kitchen floors.
Evaluate your home to determine where grab bars might help you stay upright.
Put grab bars in places where you need to maneuver or stand for a while, like a shower.
Get handrails on all stairways. In most cities, you can find an agency that will help you decide what you need and pay for these home improvements. Renters usually find that landlords agree to them.
Use the mobility aids you need. Consult an occupational therapist.
Arrange your space so you can easily reach stuff you use, to avoid stretching too high or too far in front.
Stay hydrated and don’t get too warm.

content: The San Francisco Department of Public Health also recommends seeing your doctor and checking your vision and hearing. I know some doctors prescribe bone-building drugs to fall-prone patients. Many of my MS friends take such meds.
Wheelchair Falls

People who have transitioned to mobility scooters or wheelchairs usually have fewer falls, but they still happen. Sometimes a mobility scooter tips over on a slanted or bumpy surface, or going down a curb. Sometimes users can slip out of the chair, and sometimes people fall while transferring from a chair to a toilet, bed, or shower bench.
Wheelchair users are usually more disabled and have more trouble getting up, so it’s important to follow these tips to avoid falls.
bullets: Four-wheel scooters are much more stable than three-wheel ones. I’ve had three-wheelers tip over when the bus I was riding in made a fast turn, and when I scooted across a slanted driveway. So now I always take four wheels outside.

If you find yourself sliding out of your chair after a long day out, get a seat belt. Don’t wait! They’re cheap and they work. Some power chairs have a safety harness, which secures your upper body as well as your body at waist level.
When transferring, be careful! Make sure you’re close enough and have solid places to put your hands and feet. In fact, being careful prevents falls while walking, too.

content: And a very important safety tip: Keep a mobile or cordless phone with you at all times. This has saved me twice when I fell at home with nobody else around. I could call a neighbor to help me get up. We are blessed to have cellphones. Keep yours handy.
